awd_titl_txt: Preparation of Two Taphonomic Reference Collections for Deposit in the National Taphonomic Reference Collection, Smithsonian
awd_abstract_narration:
Taphonomy, the study of how organisms fossilize, has emerged as pivotal to reconstructing ancient human lifeways, through analysis of animal bones from archaeological sites. Using taphonomic analysis, paleoanthropologists are able to decipher the source of bone accumulations at sites and provide evidence relevant to assessment of the hunting and scavenging activities of early hominins, their diet, and their utilization of skills and technologies when they migrated out of Africa and into Eurasia.

Taphonomy studies ancient bones to infer the processes that produced modifications to them, but this could never proceed without well-documented, modern reference specimens that definitively link unique bone modifications to the specific agents inflicting them. This project will accomplish preparation of nearly 4000 irreplaceable taphonomic specimens for curation in the Smithsonian Institution's new National Taphonomic Reference Collection (NTRC).  These collections, accumulated by investigators who pioneered experimental, ethno-archaeological, and landscape-scale taphonomic research in North America and Africa, cannot be reconstituted, given current legal, political, economic, and ecological circumstances.  Researchers from three continents have already utilized the collections to study bone modifications, and the value of the collections to research and teaching will continue and strengthen following their curation at the Smithsonian; the NTRC is the first taphonomy repository globally and will be a magnet for US and international paleoanthropological and paleontological researchers. 

The investigators will prepare the collections to meet the NTRC's strict standards for documentation and pest prophylaxis at the federally-compliant facilities at University of California, Santa Cruz.  Intensive involvement of undergraduate students through the university's internship program will provide invaluable training and hands-on experience with essential biological collections in contributing to US federal research infrastructure development.

por.por_cntn:
When archaeologists and human paleontologists excavate ancient evidence, they try to infer as much as possible about human behavior from it. Like crime scene investigators, prehistoric investigators aim to reconstruct behavior that they can never directly observe. Like CSI’s, as well, they strive to base their inferences on stringent standards of interpretation. In both cases, investigators often study present-day processes and their products to better understand the evidence encountered. CSI’s do controlled experiments in lab or field to better understand various patterns of evidence, such as tire tracks, footprints, blood spatter, etc.

Prehistoric investigators also do experiments: manufacturing stone tools to understand such debris at ancient sites, butchering animals with stone tools to recognize their marks on bone, feeding animal parts to captive predators to distinguish carnivore from human effects, etc. They also observe cause-and-effect relations in non-experimental, real-world situations, such as how animal bones are modified postmortem in various ecosystems, how people in rural villages produce the debris of everyday life where there are no garbage collectors, or how people make pottery and stone and metal tools for themselves. This kind of research has built up a rich reference literature for investigators seeking to reliably decipher the evidence from ancient sites.

However, chances for prehistoric researchers to study such cause-and-effect relations are rapidly vanishing on a global scale. Free-running ecosystems with larger carnivores are quickly diminishing, and more and more people are becoming urban or, if still rural, are increasingly integrated into global markets. Collections from 20th Century experiments, villages, and ecosystems have become irreplaceable reference sets for new generations of investigators seeking to understand the processes that formed ancient sites.

This National Science Foundation grant funded documentation and cleaning of the lifetime collections of two pioneers in such present-day research, to prepare the materials for deposit in the Smithsonian’s new National Taphonomic Reference Collection in the National Museum of Natural History. Taphonomy is the study of the transition of bones from their living contexts in animal bodies to fossilization. In the early 1970s Diane Gifford-Gonzalez collected food debris from a 25-year sample of Dassanetch settlements in northern Kenya. She also documented the first 10 years after death of about 40 large mammal skeletons. In the same decade, Gary Haynes began collecting animal bones from feeding experiments of captive large carnivores, and initiated a 40-year program monitoring the results of wild carnivore predation in Canada, the northern USA, and Zimbabwe, along with sustained studies of elephant life and death events. Younger investigators from Europe, Asia, and the Americas visited their collections to learn new skills in analyzing animal-bone collections.

Both researchers are now retiring. This grant has allowed them to preserve their unique collections, in database-searchable form, in a major museum accessible to present and future generations of researchers from the USA and the rest of the world.
